paper.title: Validating quantum computers using randomized model circuits

comparisons.description: 2-qubit QV circuits pass heavy output test (> 2/3)

emulator.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

tuna9.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

comparisons.description: 3-qubit QV circuits pass heavy output test (> 2/3)

emulator.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

tuna9.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

iqm_garnet.failure_description: QV n=3 HOF=63.5%, below 2/3 threshold. High variance across circuits (21.7%-96.2%). IQM Garnet native gates (prx, cz) require more decomposition for random unitaries.

emulator.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

tuna9.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

ibm_torino.failure_description: 99.99% gate fidelity. Note: inflated because IBM transpiler collapses Clifford sequences to depth 1-2 circuits, so RB measures readout error not gate error. Survival ~90% flat across all sequence lengths.
ibm_torino.note: Compilation artifact — not true gate fidelity

iqm_garnet.failure_description: RB fit gives anomalous >100% fidelity due to high variance across seeds (some near 0%, some near 100%). IQM native gate decomposition may not preserve Clifford identity at m=1. Technically passes but result is unreliable.
iqm_garnet.note: Anomalous fit — high seed-to-seed variance suggests compilation issues

summary.notes: Cross-platform comparison: QV=8 on emulator, Tuna-9, and IBM Torino. IQM Garnet passes QV n=2 but fails n=3 (high variance). RB on IBM Torino and IQM Garnet both show compilation artifacts — Clifford sequences get optimized away, making survival rates insensitive to sequence length. Tuna-9 RB (99.82%) is most reliable since cQASM compiler preserves gate structure.
